msgSnippet: At Zhanra, we require that each of our JDBC layer objects have 3 constructors.  The first one stuffs a row into the database based on a set of supplied values.

Subject: Re: [junit] an assert for testing a ResultSet
Date: Fri, 30 Mar 2001 14:25:25 -0800

From: "Chas Schley" <chas@...>

At Zhanra, we require that each of our JDBC layer objects have 3
constructors.  The first one stuffs a row into the database based on a set
of supplied values.  The second one slurps up a database row based on the
supplied key values.  The third instantiates the object based on a SQL
result set.  The latter 2 constructors speak up when an underlying data
element is missing (i.e., missing from the result set).  When you know the
key values for a particular row, use the 2nd constructor.  When you know
some but not all of the key values, or have an ad-hoc SQL query, use the 3rd
constructor.

Any class can issue a SQL query that returns one or more rows.  Using a
combination of these 3 constructors,  we can run just about any arbitrary
SQL query from anywhere (including our tests) and convert the results into
the objects that our business logic understands.  Call
assertIsNotNull(Object) on the newly constructed object to verify that the
database has your data.

Admittedly, managing constructors in the JDBC layer is a coding policy and
not a testing technique, but it achieves the same result.  Further, it
pushes some responsibility for testability onto the developers and makes our
test cases easier to write (since you can assume the existence of a given
set of constructors with a known format and function).  Test authors simply
learn the database keys and the JDBC layer becomes intuitive.

Cheers,

_chas_

> From: "Jason Trip" <jason_trip@...>
> Sent: Friday, March 30, 2001 11:23 AM
> Subject: [junit] an assert for testing a ResultSet
>

> I have a lot of tests that need to assert that data was inserted in our
> database.  Does anyone have a better way than to get a ResultSet and loop
> through with a bunch of assert statements?
>
> I thought it might be cool to have an assert that lets you pass a
resultset,
> a number of expected records, and a two-dimensional array of expected
values
> (if it could handle the data types correctly)...any other thoughts?
subject: Re: [junit] an assert for testing a ResultSet
